content.raw: A quick hack for now, until i add this code, you can change the line of the version in /nodemodules/gazebojs/packge.json to be "8.0", and the protobuf shouldn't give you an error.
content.html: A quick hack for now, until i add this code, you can change the line of the version in /nodemodules/gazebojs/packge.json to be "8.0", and the protobuf shouldn't give you an error.

This bug (that I wrote for you) affects OSRF because we often use Gazebo8 from source. Can you try this:

// msgLocator.js
'use strict'

const path = require('path')
const child_process = require('child_process')
const gazeboInfo = child_process.execSync('ls -l `which gazebo`').toString().trim()

let protoDir = null

// returns the location of a protobuf full path
// proto is the short file name of the message
function getProtoPath(proto) {

  if (!protoDir) {
    const toks = gazeboInfo.split(' ')
    // console.log('tokens',toks)
    const gazeboDir = path.dirname(toks[8])
    // console.log(gazeboDir)
    const verToks = toks[10].split('-')
    // console.log('vertoks', verToks)
    const version = verToks[1]
    // console.log('version', version)
    const maj = version.split('.')[0]
    // console.log('maj', maj)
    protoDir = path.dirname(gazeboDir) + '/include/gazebo-' + maj +
     '/gazebo/msgs/proto'

  }
  return protoDir + '/' +  proto + '.proto'
}

to use it:

const msgLocator = require('./msgLocator')
fs.existsSync(x.getProtoPath('physics'))

it should return true

content.raw:
If anyone had an Error like this

```
#!c++

Error: Illegal wire type for field Message.Field .gazebo.msgs.Pose.name: 1 (2 expected)
```
that means your gzserver version doesn't match gazebojs version in /nodemodules/gazebojs/package.json
content.html:
If anyone had an Error like this

Error: Illegal wire type for field Message.Field .gazebo.msgs.Pose.name: 1 (2 expected)

that means your gzserver version doesn't match gazebojs version in /nodemodules/gazebojs/package.json

content.raw:
# installation instructions #

```
#!c++

./deploy -m 
```

# running instructions #
start gzserver
in a separate terminal:

```
#!c++

./start_gzweb.sh
```

installation instructions

./deploy -m

running instructions

content.raw: sorry, I got the instructions wrong

gzserver must be started before deploying? That's odd. It will probably mess with thumbnail generation, because that starts several gzservers. It would be nice to have separate instructions for installing and for running.
content.html: gzserver must be started before deploying? That's odd. It will probably mess with thumbnail generation, because that starts several gzservers. It would be nice to have separate instructions for installing and for running.
